course.subject: ACCT
course.name: Accounting, Business and Society
course.description: Overview of accounting in business and social contexts; use of accounting information for accountability and decision making in companies, non-profit organizations, and government; major elements of accounting, including assets, liabilities, revenues and expenses; discharge of accountability by companies through corporate social and environmental reports.
course.exclusions: ACCT 2010, ACCT 2020

reviews.author: Kabul
reviews.title: Actually quite difficult...
reviews.comment_content:
1Ô∏è‚É£ Business and The Accounting Profession
2Ô∏è‚É£ Ethics ‚Äì CG ‚Äì CSR Framework
3Ô∏è‚É£ Foundation Concepts of Accounting
4Ô∏è‚É£ Published Financial Information
5Ô∏è‚É£ Monitoring Cash Flows for Businesses
6Ô∏è‚É£ Monitoring Assets of Business ‚Äì Long Lived Assets
7Ô∏è‚É£ Monitoring Financial Liabilities of Business
8Ô∏è‚É£ Monitoring Shareholders‚Äô Interest of Business

The course coverage is super broad. The first 30% of the course is more on SA common core related stuff such as the role of professional accounting in society, its institutional framework, and corporate governance (CG). The business ethics part is quite in depth, with discussion of fraudulent accounting practices in the now defunct Enron, industry practices and regulatory framework to ensure independence and accountability, risk management, the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, etc. We are required to do a group project on this topic as well.

The latter 70% of the course is just like a standard introductory financial accounting course, but stuff like T-accounting, accounting treatments of sales and inventory is removed. It's still quite demanding though - just imagine learning 80% of ACCT2010 with extra common-core stuff.

I know BAFS students have learned all these, and some reviews said it was not even comparable to 1 year out of its curriculum. I wonder how they all managed to go through this sh!t in their high school - this is a crazy lot of content!

Anyway I give this part an A cuz overall this course is well structured and good for learning.
reviews.comment_teaching:
‚úÖ Detailed, eloquent and illustrated with examples.
‚úÖ PowerPoint slides are on-point and visually easy to read.
‚ö†Ô∏è Attendance (be punctual!) is compulsory as Dennis will from time to time have classwork that requires you to be there in the first place.
‚ö†Ô∏è There are also some additional details that are not on the slides and we've gotta jot down notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
‚úèÔ∏è 10% Classwork
‚úèÔ∏è 25% Canvas Midterm
‚úèÔ∏è 20% Final Assignment
üìÇ 45% Group Project
      ‚úèÔ∏è 14% Interactive Activity Plan (Group)
      üí¨ 6% Presentation - Content (Group)
      üí¨ 6% Presentation - Slides (Group)
      üí¨ 12% Presentation - Skills (Individual)
      üëç 7% Peer Evaluation (Individual)

It seems that a big chunk of the grading is weighted on the project. But as it turns out everyone in the class is getting more or less similar score, so it might not be as important as the percentage suggests.

The 7% peer evaluation has a very special arrangement - it's designed to be a zero-sum game - every one of us needed to rate other group member based on a scale of 1 to 7, but on average within the group the score must averaged to be 4, so I couldn't give everybody full marks. If I gave one a higher mark, I had to deduct some points from another one. This certainly has some side effects when coupled with the P/F option this semester. In our group project meeting, we briefly shared whether each of us had applied for P/F, and what if some of us just gave the ones who applied for P/F lower marks (?)

The Canvas midterm was quite difficult. It only covered the first 3 topics and comprised of 35 multiple choice questions and 1 long question on the income statement. I thought I screwed up, but then when I looked at the mean I realized everybody else did and it turned out I was still +1.1 SD above mean (Mean = 58.96/100, SD = 16.25).

As for the project, I got
12/14 for activity plan (Mean = 10.4/14);
4.5/6 for presentation content (Mean = 4.4/6);
4.5/6 for presentation slides (Mean = 4.5/6);
9.5/12 for presentation skills (Mean = 8.9/12);
Unknown score in peer evaluation (Mean = 4/7)

Unknown score in the final assignment.
Full score in classwork.

Applied for P/F, and I received a Pass grade at the end. So I can't really gauge the grading.
reviews.comment_workload:
The highlight of the course is definitely the group project on business ethics and corporate governance. It consists of a 12-min presentation and a plan of an interactive activity (e.g. a game, a role play) hypothetically designed for a class of 40 high school students. We are required to include examples related to our own major. Since the students enrolling in this course are mainly from science and engineering, the standard of presentation and delivery might not be as high compared to other business courses. Overall I believe this project is indeed worth working hard. I remember there have been some case competitions on corporate governance and ESG reporting, and at that time I had no idea what corporate governance was.

Everything else was okay until the final assignment. This assignment was submitted near the end of the semester. It's super challenging, requiring us to read real financial statements in the Annual Report of Apple and give general comments of a company's financial position. The annoying part is that Dennis requires our answers to be hand-written on the answer sheets printed out from his template. I had to go to my nearby Âø´ÂúñÁæé, spend money to print out his template answer sheets, scribble 10 pages of trash on the answer sheets, go to Âø´ÂúñÁæé again to scan them back and submit them online. You can imagine how stupid this fucking thing is for me, a poor guy with a printer that just unfortunately broke down when I needed it. Another thing was that the 7 pages of answer sheet he provided were not enough - I submitted 10 pages at last...

Other parts of workload include classwork (a total of 9 randomly distributed throughout the whole semester, READ: compulsory attendance), and preparation for the Canvas midterm.

reviews.title: ACCT 1010
reviews.comment_content: The contents is interesting and not difficult to understand. Basically, if you have taken some relative courses in high school, this course would a piece of cake for you. But still need to bear in mind the memorization is are required for this course.
reviews.comment_teaching: As long as you are not sleepy, listening to Dennis is quite interesting as he could tell you some little business stories.
reviews.comment_grading: Mean B-
reviews.comment_workload:
There is a project about designing a game or a workshop for the children about business ethics. This is an easy project comparing to other projects in common core courses.

You have to attend guest talks sometimes but the regular lecture would cancelled.

There would be quiz in-class accounted for participation marks.

reviews.author: takecare
reviews.title: Realize why business courses are praised with highest prestige in terms of grading and teaching at UST.
reviews.comment_content:
T1. Business and The Accounting Profession

T2. Ethics ‚Äì CG ‚Äì CSR Framework (Ethics, Corporate Governance (CG), and Corporate Social Responsibility (CSR))

3 Guest lectures

T3. Foundation Concepts of Accounting

T4. Published Financial Information

T7. Monitoring Assets of Business ‚Äì Long Lived Assets

T8. Monitoring Financial Liabilities of Business

T9. Monitoring Shareholders‚Äô Interest of Business

Reading
Textbook (HSEP):
Horngren, Charles T., Sundem, Gary L., Elliot, John A., and Philbrick, D., ‚ÄúIntroduction
to Financial Accounting‚Äù, 11th edition, Pearson New International Edition, 2014.

Other References:
Duska, R., Duska, Brenda S., and Ratgatz, Julie A., ‚ÄúAccounting Ethics‚Äù. 2nd edition,
Wiley, 2011. (DDR)

The project is based on, T1, T2 and the 3 guest lectures. The final exam covers T3, T4, T7, T8 and T9. It is a valuable course, even though T5 and T6 are even excluded.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dennis is very helpful. He is a nice guy to answer your question in class and email in a clear and structured detail. I also get his advice about looking for internships in financial institutions like the Big 4. I am glad to be his student.
reviews.comment_grading: The grade is surprisingly good! Even though the project result is below mean, it is unbelievable that my friend and I get A range, especially when the final exam is more difficult than we think. I am so grateful that I used to think I might not be able to grasp a good grade as there are so many people studied in accounting in the course.
reviews.comment_workload:
Attending every class is easy. Classwork is just counted as attendance. No marks will be deducted if you have a wrong answer.
The project workload is not a burden. If your team work so hard, the honorarium (over $1000) will be given for external presentation. It is highly recommended.

reviews.author: Á•ûÊúà godmoon
reviews.title: Introductory course of Accounting (Non-accounting background)
reviews.comment_content:
Topics: (‚≠ê means Difficulties)
T01. Business and The Accounting Profession
T02. Ethics/Corporate Governance CSR Framework
T03. Foundation Concepts of Accounting
T04. Measuring Income to Assess Performance
T05. Accrual Accounting and Financial Statements
T06. ‚≠êStatement of Cash Flow
T07. Accounting for Sales
T08. Inventories and Cost of Goods Sold
T09. Long-lived Assets and Depression
T10. ‚≠êLiabilities and Interest
T11. ‚≠êStockholder‚Äôs Equity

Required Textbook (HSEP): Introduction to Financial Accounting by Horngren, Charles T., Sundem,
Gary L., Elliot, John A., and Philbrick, D., 11th edition, Pearson New International Edition, 2014.
References:
Accounting Ethics by Duska, R., Duska, Brenda S., and Ratgatz, Julie A., 2nd edition, Wiley, 2011.
(DDR)
--------------------------------

This course is different from the 2000-level courses by focusing not on the mechanics, but more on the purposes, features, and values of different accounting practices for businesses
and society. The increasing use of principles-based accounting standards and the ethical issues thereof will be highlighted for students‚Äô attention.

In general, I think the content is very useful for getting the basic picture of the financial world. But the content is actually quite difficult.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Instructor: Zilan Yang (Ph.D. student in accounting)

Well-Written Notes.
Clear Explanation.
Fluent Speaking and interesting real-life examples.
Accounting is boring but Zilan makes the lecture interesting

**********
Please noted that the comments are written from the experience of lectures offered by Professor Yang.
Please also noted that the summer course syllabus may vary from the regular semesters.
reviews.comment_grading:
Class Participation 10%
Assignment 10%
Quizzes (best two out of three) 40% (20% each)
Final Exam 40%
Total 100%
--------------------------------------
My Score:
Participation: 10/10 (mean:9.25)
Homework: 10/10 (mean: 10)
Quiz: Only the best two out of three will be graded:
Quiz1:92/100 (Mean: 70.24 Median: 72 High: 94 Upper Quartile: 84 Low: 34 Lower Quartile: 58)
Quiz2: 74/100 (Mean: 78.24 Median: 77.5 High: 97.5 Upper Quartile: 85 Low: 60 Lower Quartile: 72.5)
Quiz3: 95/100 (Mean: 83.68 Median: 85 High: 97.5 Upper Quartile: 92.5 Low: 30 Lower Quartile: 82.5)
Final Exam: 80.33/100 (Mean: 69.29 Median: 71.67 High: 92 Upper Quartile: 75.67 Low: 40 Lower Quartile: 61)

Grade: A

The grading is fair/ quite good as it seems to follow the normal distribution.

The quiz is very easy but you have to compete with the time as you need to finish 50MCQ in just 40minutes.
Please also be noted that the final exam is much more complicated than the quiz.

The grading and the format may vary from semester to semester
--------------------------------------------

For participation, if you submit the in-class exercises, you can get a full score. There will be only five in-class exercises.

For the Homework, it is graded on your effort. As long as you submit the assignment, you will get the full mark.
reviews.comment_workload:
Only weekly assignments with two to three questions.
In-class assignments but you can actually complete them on your own without actually attending the lectures.

The competition of this course is very little. In the first lecture, the professor asked which major we are studying, and most of the students are also non-SBM students and non-BAFS students such as Civil Engineering and Mathematics. Due to the exclusion of ACCT 2010, I think in general, everyone has roughly the same background in accounting and the grade is hugely dependent on your effort.

*****
If you have some background in the fundamental analysis of stock ( e.g. PE ratio, stock dividend split, compliance, depreciation, interest rate) or you are familiar with the market trend, it could help you a lot.

reviews.author: Yin111
reviews.comment_content:
Easy content
It includes some DSE things like accrual and prepaid rent, accumulated depreciation.
But there is something different so you need to listen carefully.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Wang Hui is a good instructor.
She explained everything clearly and she answer students' questions in details earnestly.
And her english is clear and easy to understand.
However, the lecture is 3 hours long so it is a little bit boring.
reviews.comment_grading:
Good grade.
Three quiz and one final exam.
I got almost full mark in all quizzes
Score for final exam was not released.
Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Small workload.
1 assignment every week, which is easy.
I used about 1 hour for every assignment.
And the final exam and quizzes are easy to get high mark.

reviews.author: Rynnie
reviews.comment_content: His content gives an adequate explanation for you to understand basic accounting, and sometimes provides you farther sources.
reviews.comment_teaching: You would be able to understand all content if you follow the professor's instructions and read the materials.
reviews.comment_grading: His tests include errors, but there was no correction or adjustment. The midterm was short on time, so keep that in mind. His grading is rational for the projects, concentrates on how much you gave detail, and followed the instruction.
reviews.comment_workload: The final assignment was challenging, but the tests and the projects could be completed with 10 days cramming.

reviews.comment_content:
Cover the basics of accounting

T1. Business and The Accounting Profession
T2. Ethics ‚Äì CG ‚Äì CSR Framework
T3. Foundation Concepts of Accounting
T4. Published Financial Information
T5. Monitoring Cash Flows for Businesses

reviews.author: zoooob
reviews.comment_content:
T1. Business and The Accounting Profession
T2. Ethics ‚Äì CG ‚Äì CSR Framework
T3. Foundation Concepts of Accounting
T4. Published Financial Information
T5. Monitoring Cash Flows for Businesses
T6. Monitoring Assets of Business ‚Äì Long Lived Assets
T7. Monitoring Financial Liabilities of Business
T8. Monitoring Shareholders‚Äô Interest of Business

The course covers a wide range of topics. I think it will not be hard to handle for those who studied BAFS in secondary school before. However, double entry system is not applied in this course, so you still have to pay attention in the lectures. If you didn't study it before, you may consider to take this course or not as it may be a little bit difficult to digest and understand the accounting entries within a short time of period.

The group presentation and interactive activity plan are related to the first two topics. It's about going to secondary school to give a 12-minute presentation and one-hour interactive activity to students like playing games or role play in order to raise their understanding on business ethics and corporate governance.

The quiz covered the first three topics and actually it emphasised quite a lot on T3 which requires more accounting concepts and calculations.

The assignment covered the remaining topics (except T8 as we didn't have enough time to teach). But to be honest, the questions are really complicated. They require you to comment on some situation or do calculations. You may need a lot of time to think how to work them out.

Classwork are out randomly during the lectures. One mark is awarded for good efforts. If you didn't attend the lecture and but the classwork, he didn't count your mark anyway.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dennis explained the concepts clearly with many examples. Powerpoint slides are organised and easy to read. He paused from time to time to see if there are any questions. His teaching is good.

Classwork 10%

-Interactive activity plan (Group)14%
-Presentation ‚Äìcontent (Group) 6%

-Presentation ‚Äìskills (Individual) 12%
-Peer evaluation (Individual) 7%

My case:
CW: 9/9
Quiz: 91/100 (Mean: 58.96; S.D:16.25)
Interactive activity plan: 13/14
Presentation ‚Äìcontent: 5.5/6
Presentation ‚Äìslides: 4.5/6
Presentation ‚Äìskills: 9/12
Peer evaluation: unknown
Assignment: unknown

As i saw from goop, the opinions towards the grading is diverse, but I think you may attain a satisfactory grade if you perform well in the group presentation since it accounts for 45% of the course. At last I got an A+ for this course.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload is light. There is only one assignment due at the end of the semester and you are given around 3 weeks to finish it. There are also a group presentation and interactive activity plan regarding business ethics and corporate governance. It may not be very difficult as long as you don't meet any freeriders.

reviews.author: jokkkkkk
reviews.comment_content: the course introduces some basic knowledge of accounting. some of them are quite basic, but there are lots of formulas needed to memorize.
reviews.comment_teaching: the professor is patient and the teaching is quite great.
reviews.comment_grading: fair. i got almost the highest mark of the group project but only reached the mean score in final and i got B. Also around 4 of the best group projects would be chosen to present in the secondary schools with awards and prices.
reviews.comment_workload: the workload is not heavy at all. the group project is easy to finish, and throughout the semesters there would be quizzes for few times, therefore the attendance is important. However, as i said, there are a lot to memorise for the final exam.

reviews.author: Beth
reviews.comment_content:
T1. Business and The Accounting Profession
T2. Ethics ‚Äì CG ‚Äì CSR Framework
T3. Foundation Concepts of Accounting
T4. Published Financial Information
T5. Monitoring Cash Flows for Businesses

reviews.author: lllllllllllllll
reviews.title: Introductory Accounting Course
reviews.comment_content:
Topic 1: Business and the Accounting Profession
Topic 2: Ethics - Corporate Governance - CSR Framework
Topic 3: Foundation Concepts of Accounting
Topic 4: Published and Financial Information
Topic 5: Monitoring Cash Flows for Business
Topic 6: Monitoring Asses of Businesses - Long-lived Assets
Topic 7: Monitoring Financial Liabilities of Business
Topic 8: Monitoring Stockholder's Interests of Business

Basically, you will learn most if not all the fundamental concepts of accounting.
reviews.comment_teaching: Dennis is a very good, kind and organized professor. The classes are easy to understand since he tries to interact with the students by asking questions in class. His explanations of concepts are clear, and he is very approachable and willing to answer any questions that students may have. If you are unclear about anything, the class, the content, or the assignments, Dennis will happily help you clear things up. The pace of the class follows very closely with the schedule that the professor hands out in the beginning of the semester.
reviews.comment_grading:
Dennis is a very reasonable professor, so the grading seems fair.

There are many students that have previously taken accounting courses in their high school, they will raise the mean of the final exams :)

The final exam consisted of 50 marks - MCQ (25 questions) and 50 marks - long questions.
The statistics on the final exam are unknown.
reviews.comment_workload:
2 compulsory guest lectures that you have to attend to. (counts 2% to your grade)

Personally, it was a lot of content to revise for the examinations, if you have not studied accounting before. The textbook questions are not mandatory, but it is recommended that you do them. Be mindful that the final exam questions are slightly more difficult than the textbook questions.

The workload for the group project seems fair. You are grouped with 6 people. Note, to prevent any free-riders, you are required to submit a peer-evaluation form (which also counts toward your project grade)

See the attached for the details/requirements.

Grade is quite good, especially for the group project, Dennis usually gives a pretty good grade for the groups. Mean is around B-.

reviews.comment_workload:
7 classwork in total: Easy and can be done under discussing with classmates or even ask Dennis.

Mid-term exam is covering T1-T4, usually held during Week 14 or 15.

1 group project, workload won't be too high if you are working with good or fair group mates. But it is usually the part that every student of this course are paying the most effort in, because it is sharing 43% of the course.

1 final exam, covering T5-T8

The best thing of the exams is that the final exam is not covering all topics throughout the whole course, but only those that are not being examined during the mid-term, less things to be memorized.

reviews.author: maxfung
reviews.title: Basic Acct
reviews.comment_content: This course introduces students to professional accounting and its roles in business and society.  It starts with explaining how businesses can be set up in different forms and with different objectives, of which respective interested parties (i.e. stakeholders) are affected.  Stakeholders include shareholders, investors, managers,  employees,  creditors,  suppliers,  government  and  regulatory  agencies  etc.  The  assurance  of stakeholders‚Äô  interests  relies  on  ethics  and  good  governance  practiced  by  businesses.  Accounting information is used by stakeholders in decision making, as well as ensuring ethical and socially responsible behavior from managers concerned. By virtue of  its extensive usage, accounting is the knowledge, and also the skills, that every person should know at different extent in order to understand and evaluate how businesses are operated as responsible corporate citizens.

reviews.author: ayymiami
reviews.title: Good Introductory Business Course
reviews.comment_content: The course covers a lot of the basic concepts regarding accounting. From balance sheets and a plethora of relevant ratios and factors that help understand financial data to the fundamental ethics that one must follow in the field of business and accounting which have in the past been in the spotlight for various acts of fraud and crime, this course gives you a good introduction as a non-SBM student. The nature of accounting is such that you do have to memorize quite a lot of information though :/
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is one of the main reasons this course is worth taking. He speaks very well and explains concepts  precisely, making them pretty easy to understand. He is very open to receiving questions from everyone at any point in class and also after class. Prof replies to emails fairly efficiently and quickly.
reviews.comment_grading:
Make a good project and work well with your team to maximize on that opportunity, I believe the team project varies from year to year so just focus on what task is given to you.
Neither the midterm nor the final are exceptionally hard nor are they easy, requiring you to think quite a bit on the subjective questions. Be careful with calculations for the balance sheet and numerical questions though.
reviews.comment_workload: The course has a light workload except for the group project, which mostly needs you to brainstorm on ideas.

reviews.author: Paulma
reviews.comment_content:
Not difficult at all
just need to remember some  financial terms and imple math calculations
The exam is based on notes and quiz. Especially, The calculation question is simliar to note content and quiz.Be familar with calculation parts would help you a lot since it occupies a high ratio marks for the exam and quiz. Also MC question is important and some True Flase question.

3 online quizs
1 final

The note is quite long
Averagely, one lesson finishes one lecture and has about 50 mins quiz. Total in 3 quizs.
Therefore, you would feel boring because the lecturer read through the note.
However, the lecturer has a passion for teaching and will to answer question
reviews.comment_grading:
It is quite great. My online quiz is below mean a little bit. However, My exam is higher than mean (8x). My final exam 9x.
As a result, I got a B+
reviews.comment_workload:
Not too much workload.
Fair
Since no project.
Only 3 quizs , around 9 assignment and 1 final. No mid-term

reviews.author: Khushi Chawla
reviews.comment_content: The course was very short and had 3 classes in a week for about 3 hrs each, which was a little hectic but nonetheless it was a very interesting course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor was really kind and helpful. The lecture slides prepared were really detailed and you didn't need to study from anywhere else.
reviews.comment_grading:
The course is a bit tough to score in as the class size is really small and since the grading is based on a curve it can be hard to get in the A range.

Course grading:
2 out of 3 quizzes - 20% x 2 = 40% (MCQ + Transaction Analysis)
Homework - 10%
Class Participation - 10%
Final exam - 40% (MCQ +T/F + Transaction Analysis)

I got full in homework, class participation, and both quizzes
95/100 in the final exam

Ended up getting an A.
Would only suggest the course to those who have a good command of accounting or are keen to learn.
reviews.comment_workload: The workload wasn't much. You get homework almost after every class but the homework isn't graded only the submission score is counted. The quizzes arent very difficult, most of the stuff you can find in the slides but you need to work hard to get all the transaction questions correct.

AssessmentsStudents taking this course will be assessed by classworks, quiz, group project, and the final examination.   Classworkswill  be  handed  out  randomly  throughout  the  term,  and  to  be completed by students during lectures.  Marks will be awarded for efforts made by students in  completing  classwork.   One  quizwill  be  open-book  and held  during  lectures.    Both classworks  and  quizare intended  for  helping  students  to  apply  and  consolidate  what  they learn in lectures in a timely manner.  Group project provides the opportunityfor studentstowork as a team,andto think through and appreciate the importance and relevance of ethics tobusiness and professional practice.  Deliverables of group project include a presentation, a report and a peer evaluation.  Details of group project are provided in a separate Project Brief.  Final examination will beclosed-book and comprised of multiple choice and long questions.
